results.title: Le Destin de Juliette = the Destiny of Juliette
results.brief_description:
Aline Isserman’s film chronicles twenty years of a woman’s life. Juliette, a simple country girl, is in love with Pierre, a sheperd but she is forced into a marriage with a boring railway worker in order to save her family from poverty and homelessness. The husband, Marcel, is transferred from post to post, and becomes an alcoholic, eventually dying, leaving Juliette free to rebuild her life.

Credits: Producer, Eric Lambert ; director, Aline Isserman ; writers, Michel Dufresne, Aline Isserman ; photography, Dominique Le Rigoleur ; music, Bernard Lubat.
Cast: Laure Duthilleul, Richard Bohringer, Veronique Silver, Pierre Forget, Hippolyte Girardot.

results.title: La Proie Pour L'ombre = Shadow of Adultery (Cinemascope Print)
results.brief_description:
The wife of a rich building contractor, beginning to tire of being merely a social asset to her husband, finds an outlet by running an art gallery and taking a lover. In the end, she sacrifices both men for her independence. White sports cars, cocktail parties, an art gallery, a recording studio, modern skyscrapers, jazz and Bach on the soundtrack and quick, slick cross-cutting, give Astruc’s contribution to the ‘Nouvelle Vague’ an over-riding air of chic. In this film Astruc is also influenced by Japanese filmmaker Mizoguchi (‘Tales of a Pale Moon After the Rain’) for whom he had great admiration.

Credits: Producer, Leopold Schlosberg ; director, Alexandre Astruc ; writers, Alexandre Astruc, Claude Brule ; photography, Marcel Grignon ; music, Richard Cornu, Jean-Sebastien Bach ; art direction ; Jacques Saulnier.
Cast: Annie Girardot, Christian Marquand, Daniel Gelin, Michele Girardon, Michele Gerbier.

results.title: Trans Europ Express
results.brief_description:
A film director, on the Trans Europ Express from Paris to Antwerp, decides to write a script about a sadistic drug smuggler on his way to Antwerp to collect a shipment of cocaine. There, the character gets involved with a prostitute and is caught up in a series of perilous situations. Reference: Bloomsbury Foreign Film Guide.

Credits: Producer, Samy Halfon ; director, writer, Alain Robbe-Grillet ; photography, Willy Kurant.
Cast: Jean-Louis Trintignant, Marie-France Pisier, Daniel Emilfork.

results.title: Therese Desqueyroux
results.brief_description:
Therese, finding herself stifled by provincial life and a dull marriage, decides to poison her boring but inoffensive husband. Emanuelle Riva subtly portrays the psychological and physical deterioration of Therese, while director Franju succeeds in capturing the oppressiveness of the natural world around her. Awards: Venice Film Festival 1962: Best Actress for Emanuelle Riva.

Credits: Producer, Robert Vignon ; director, Georges Franju ; writers, Francois Mauriac, Claude Mauriac, Georges Franju ; photography, Christian Matras ; music, Maurice Jarre.
Cast: Emanuelle Riva, Philippe Noiret, Edith Scob, Renee Devillers, Helene Dieudonne, Jeanne Perez, Sami Frey, Jacques Monod, Lucien Nat, Richard Saint-Bris.

results.title: Mandrin (Cinemascope Print)
results.brief_description:
Mandrin is a French version of Robin Hood, a man who decides to deal in his own way with greedy tax collectors and redistribute the wealth to the people.

Credits: Director, Jean-Paul Le Chanois ; writers, Jean-Paul Le Chanois, Rene Havard, Claude Desailly, Lois Martin.
Cast: Georges Riviere, Silvia Montfort, Armand Mestral, Dany Robin, Maurice Baquet, Georges Wilson.

results.title: Six Chevaux Bleus = Six Blue Horses
results.brief_description:
A Chinese man inherit six blue porcelain horses and discovers that one of them contains the combination to a safe filled with diamonds. In order to recover the diamonds which are guarded by an antiquarian, the old man’s nephews must contend with a gang of criminals.

Credits: Producer, Michel Peynet ; director, Philippe Joulia ; writers, Philippe Joulia, Yves Desmoulin ; photography, Jacques Ledoux ; music, Antoine Duhamel.
Cast: Henri Cremieux, Yvonne Clech, Corinne Le Poulain, Patrick Boitet, Pascal Boitet.

results.title: La Chaise Vide = the Empty Chair
results.brief_description:
Anne is raising her child alone and works in a photo library. She is waiting for her reporter lover to return from the war in Africa and refuses any offer to start a new life with Maxime, a musician.

Credits: Director, Pierre Jallaud ; writers, Pierre Jallaud, Maxime Le Forestier ; photography, Georges Barsky ; music, Maxime Le Forestier.
Cast: Martine Chevalier, Daniel Quenaud, Maxime Le Forestier, Cyril Stockman, Evane Hanska.

results.title: Le Jour Se Leve = Daybreak
results.brief_description:
Poetic realism is a phrase often used in association with Carne’s work, and there could be no better example of this particular style than ‘Le jour se leve’. The setting is the ‘banlieue’ of a French industrial town - recreated in studio by Alexandre Trauner - and it would be hard to disagree with Gavin Lambert’s comment in ‘Sequence’ in 1948 that ‘there is no other film which has conveyed so intensely the drama, irony and nostalgias of urban life’. The narrative of ‘Le jour se leve’ condenses into one night action which covers a considerably longer period. On the night in question, Francois, a factory worker, has killed Valentin, who has a small music-hall act, and awaits the inevitable arrival of the police. In the meantime, he remembers the events which led up to the murder. Added to the abstract sense of determinism ‘Le jour se leve’ has a social and political dimension reflecting the climate of despair gripping France just prior to WWII. This feeling was particularly acute among the working class which had pinned so much hope on the Popular Front government, only to have them dashed by its too rapid disintegration and by the renewed offensives of the Right. The contrast with earlier films such as Renoir’s ‘Le crime de monsieur Lange’ (1935) and ‘La Marseillaise’ (1938), and even Duvivier’s ‘La belle equipe’ (1936), with their hope and optimism is both striking and depressing. The feeling of comradeship and solidarity is gone. The scene in which Arletty appears naked had to be cut to allow for the film to be released. ‘Le jour se leve’ was then regarded as ‘demoralising’ by the Vichy government which attempeted to ban all films affiliated with the ‘poetic realism’ style. The film was re-made as an American film noir as ‘The Long Night’ (1947) directed by Anatole Litvak, starring Henry Fonda.

Credits: Producer, Paul Madeux ; writers, Jacques Prevert, Jacques Viot ; photography, Curt Courant, Philippe Agostini ; music, Maurice Jaubert ; art direction, Alexandre Trauner ; stills photography, Raymond Voinquel.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Arletty, Jacqueline Laurent, Jules Berry, Bernard Blier.

results.title: La Tete Contre les Murs = the Keepers
results.brief_description:
Francois Gerane is convinced his father, a famous lawyer, has killed his mother. Using as a pretext one of Francois’s small misdeed, Maitre Gerane has the rebellious young man committed to a mental home. Much of Franju’s first feature was shot in an actual asylum. The film is essentially a plea for a more sensible treatment of the mentally ill and the emotionally distressed, calling for much-needed widespread reforms. ‘La tete contre les murs’ is surely the most beautiful French film made since the war, and possibly the most beautiful French film ever made.” Reference: POSITIF, 1/7/1959.

Credits: Producer, Jerome Goulven ; director, Georges Franju ; writers, Jean-Charles Pichon, Jean-Pierre Mocky ; photography, Eugene Schuftan ; music, Maurice Jarre ; assistant director, Jacques Rouffio ; camera assistant, Claude Zidi.
Cast: Jean-Pierre Mocky, Anouk Aimee, Pierre Brasseur, Charles Aznavour, Paul Meurisse, Jean Galland, Edith Scob, Jean Ozenne.
